thread.title: Muscat shock candidate for Euro job: report
thread.title_full: Muscat shock candidate for Euro job: report

title: Muscat shock candidate for Euro job: report
text:
Kevin Muscat linked with Scottish club Rangers’ coach role: report Staff writers with AAP, FOX SPORTS February 17, 2017 10:06am 
KEVIN Muscat is a shock candidate for the Rangers head coach role, according to The Sun. 
The Melbourne Victory coach has led his side to second in the A-League after 19 Rounds and is set to take Victory into the Asian Champions League. 
However, the report details that Muscat is as a contender to take over from Mark Warburton at the Scottish club after building a reputation at the Australian outfit. 
Rangers chiefs are compiling a shortlist of candidates, and Muscat is reportedly an outsider for the role. 
The 44-year-old spent a year at Scottish club Ibrox in Alex McLeish’s treble-winning squad in 2003. media_camera Melbourne Victory coach Kevin Muscat. 
After Victory’s goalless draw with Newcastle last week, Muscat said the team “shot ourselves in the foot”. 
Victory were lax and largely outplayed by Newcastle in Monday night’s goalless draw, just the second time they have failed to score this season. 
It was a missed opportunity to widen the seven-point gap on third-placed Brisbane, while Sydney FC now lead the league by 11 points with eight regular- season games remaining. 
Victory now have one win from the last five games. 
The result was also their ninth winless match in 10 outings at McDonald Jones Stadium, a veritable graveyard for the three-time champions. Muscat lamented his side’s lack of intensity and structure in a sluggish first term, when uncharacteristic turnovers afforded the enterprising Jets possession and territory. 
“All their attacking movement came from us giving the ball away, especially square,” Muscat said. Were Victory robbed? 0:39 
A-League: Victory midfielder James Troisi went down in the box with just minutes remaining with his teammates calling for the referee to award a penalty. February 13th 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/Football/A-League/ Were Victory robbed? 
“When you’re playing the ball square to someone you’ve got to be safe. “When we do win the ball back a lot of (our) players are going forward. “You decide to go square and it gets cut out, you’re eliminating up to five of your teammates. 
“We shot ourselves in the foot. 
“We walk away frustrated, very, very frustrated.” Victory didn’t spring to life until the final 20 minutes when Daniel Georgievski hit the woodwork - one of nine shots to Newcastle’s 18 - and could count themselves lucky their hosts on occasions lacked polish. 
Perhaps more concerning is that the lower-placed Jets, who have now squeezed into the top six, kept attacking stars Marco Rojas and Besart Berisha quiet. Muscat was reluctant to reflect on his team’s rapidly dwindling Premiers’ Plate hopes. 
“That ain’t going to help me,” he said. 
“What I can change from now until Central Coast (on Sunday) is our performance... so I’ll spend all my energy there.” 
- Additional reporting with AAP.
